diagrams.description: Textile Engineering encompasses fiber types, manufacturing processes, fabric structures, and functional applications creating materials for diverse industries. Fiber categories include natural plant fibers like cotton, linen, and hemp, natural animal fibers like wool and silk, synthetic polymers including polyester, nylon, and acrylic, regenerated fibers like rayon and lyocell, and high-performance fibers including aramids, carbon fiber, and ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene. Yarn production methods employ ring spinning producing fine strong yarns, open-end rotor spinning for high-speed production, air-jet spinning using compressed air, friction spinning for bulky yarns, and core-spun yarns combining materials. Fabric construction techniques feature plain weave with simple over-under pattern, twill weave creating diagonal lines, satin weave producing smooth lustrous surface, weft knitting forming courses horizontally, warp knitting creating vertical loops, and nonwoven bonding fibers mechanically, thermally, or chemically. Finishing processes include mechanical finishing like calendering and raising, chemical finishing applying softeners and water repellents, dyeing using various methods and colorants, printing creating patterns through screen or digital printing, and functional treatments adding flame retardancy, antimicrobial properties, or UV protection. Technical textiles span geotextiles for civil engineering, medical textiles for healthcare, protective textiles for safety, automotive textiles for vehicles, and smart textiles integrating sensors and electronics. Testing methods measure tensile strength and elongation, abrasion resistance, pilling propensity, colorfastness to various agents, dimensional stability, and comfort properties like moisture management and breathability.
